job_title: Patient Care Technician in Birmingham, AL
pros: Benefits (medical, dental, and vision) are wonderful, flexibility of schedule as a student is unparalleled, PTO accrual rates are solid, end of year bonuses (while dependent on how well the year goes for the hospital) aren't terrible, and optional overtime pay is usually worth it.
cons: Base pay rates are much lower than at other hospitals in the area and this is viewed as something you accept if working at COA because they have a monopoly on the patient population (pediatrics). Staffing ratios and staff retention could be improved by adjusting base pay rates.

pros: I worked with a great team. Analysts that worked with the end user really made life easy for me as a developer. Great manager and did what they said they would. This was one of the best teams I've been on.
cons: My decision to leave was based mostly on the organization's politics. Since the hospital is beholding to the federal government, you can see where this is going. I don't approve nor will I ever on some of the ridiculous add ons for their annual curriculum and especially mandates on poorly tested vaccine(s). Money is always an issue when you're skillset isn't met with the going rate. So the low pay scale is a real thing but I don't necessarily blame the hospital for this. That's the individual's responsibility to make sure they get hired with a wage they are comfortable with. However, if your worth is not being met as time goes on, it becomes a task of looking for new employment. I was given sound advice a long time ago..."do what you got to do"....and that's exactly what I do .

pros: The work is very rewarding and I feel like I make a difference in my patient’s lives.
cons: Very short staffed. Pay is not adequate for what my job entails.

review_title: Positive Culture, Outstanding Staff, Supportive Management, Rewarding Work
pros: Managers are approachable and engaged in daily operations; they lead by example and are supportive of subordinates. The culture is encouraging, and the work is rewarding. Response to challenges resulting from Covid has been quite generous.
cons: Compensation is the one thing holding COA back. While modest year-end bonuses and annual merit increases are appreciated, they are not a substitute for a competitive base. The range spread for many 'rank and file' roles is excessively broad (50%); as a consequence, some employees are hired well below market. Pay compression is a significant problem, and it appears that little is being done to address it. It kills morale and discourages performance when newly hired employees are earning as much or more than the most experienced and productive personnel. Performance is likewise disincentivized by misguided practices that more or less reward everyone equally regardless of individual contributions.

pros: children, architecture, employees, free standing hospital in alabama
cons: salary, no holiday pay, no weekend pay

pros: I was a CNA and I enjoyed working with my patients.  I also enjoyed some of the staff.
cons: Very low pay and my experience of being an LPN in the Air Force did not give me any credit or allow me to use it towards my job.  I left straight from the AF and came to work and CHS, it seemed like I got demoted.  I went from getting around $15-16/hr to $9/hr.  I also was starting IV's, doing blood draws, suturing up lacerations, putting in G-tubes and J-tubes, working in GI removing polyps in, assisting in ERCP's, assisting in colonoscopies, and so much more.  Then at CHS all I could do was vital signs and change bedding.  The work was tough and not worth $9/hr.  Some of the nurses and doctors are cocky and if you aren't a nurse or doctor they feel that they are superior to you.

pros: Patients are great. Benefits are okay. I love the job.
cons: Management is all talk but never follow through. You can tell them what is going on wrong and they see what is going on but they never do anything. They just pretend like you never told them anything. That's a hospital wide situation a lot of managers know there are people taking advantage of the system. Not working and putting their work load on others and getting away with it and management make excuses for them. Management also treats those who do their work and what they're supposed to do like crap which is why people are leaving. They're just tired of it! Leaders in certain departments are allowed to pick on and treat employees horrible.

review_title: Overall, Children's Hospital is a great organization with a great purpose of taking care of sick children
pros: Lot of wonderful employees working together to improve the health of those kids we serve. The atmosphere is very good and a very happy one. Overall, the staffing in each of the departments seems to be reasonable. We are now in the brand new state of the art hospital that is beautiful and gives employees a great place to work every day.
cons: The top leadership at the hospital are not a cohesive group and they often times pulling in different directions. Some lack the skills to lead the departments they are responsible for.

review_title: Children's Health System: An excellent place to work and grow in a career and in life.
pros: The hospital management is very supportive of personal and professional growth.  They are understanding of family issues and give their employees the time and support needed to manage all of the areas of their lives.  For example they have a day care program for new mothers where the new babies can attend up to 6 months of age and where mildly ill children can be cared for while their parents are working.
cons: I haven't found many "downsides."  With as many employees as Children's has, you know there will be differences of opinions but I haven't had any problems that couldn't be resolved.  The management even encourages classes that help us learn to problem solve and give constructive feedback.  These classes aren't just for the management team either.

pros: Great mission to help children
cons: Unwritten policies and procedures that are applied inconsistently and unfairly.  Written policies are old and do not coincide with actual practices.  Policies vary from dept to dept. No adherence to DOL laws regarding exempt/non exempt pay & OT. No accountability for upper management/execs.  Managers are given a title with no mgt training required.  Flying by the seat of their pants is the feel.  They’re all about the show and the money.

pros: Working with children making a impact on their lives.. lunches are great all around area..plenty of discounts and you can wear t shirts instead of scrubs tops.
cons: Well first off HR needs to get their act together, I was hired well rehired started orientation and BOOM!! I was ushered to a conference room with HR to find out that I had a outstanding warrant from almost 10 years ago I knew nothing about. It’s funny because I actually worked for Children’s 5 years ago and nothing showed up! Been overseas and out of town working my background been ran extensively nothing....👀👀 needless to say  they should actually make sure everything is ok BEFORE having someone quit their previous job only to be FIRED by the new one!!

review_title: The place to be a kid, and a Nurse
pros: This is an amazing and different atmosphere for Hospital Nurses.  It's completely geared for Children and making them feel comfortable and safe.  The work can be hard, and some things are just heartbreaking to see and handle.  But as the nurse you help families through these difficult day.  And no matter what the kids are going through, the fact remains that they are still kids.  Curious, funny and resilient.  There are many capacities, schedules and locations that a Registered Nurse can choose to work in.
cons: The pay here is the lowest in the city for nurses.  The starting pay is low and the raises are meager.

pros: The people I worked with were the only positive thing to say about working on that unit.  They kept me sane when I wanted to leave the job on a daily basis.
cons: Horrible management.  Demeaning, would not assist employees or listen to their complaints.  No help at all from DON, assistant nurse managers, etc.  From the week I first started there, all I heard were negative comments from employees telling me it was the worst place to work.  Only lasted a year there and it was probably the worst job I have ever worked at.

review_title: Great staff, employer whose mission, vision and values can be supported.
pros: Children's has great benefits for the area and competitive salaries.  Time off is generous.  It is easy to support the mission, vision and values of the organization.  Patients and their families are grateful for the work you do.  Staff are often long term.
cons: Opportunities for advancement are hard to come by.  Many of the senior leadership have been with the organization 20+ years and are not expected to retire for another 10-15 years.  The close working relationship with UAB can be a political minefield.

job_title: Corporate Communications Intern in Birmingham, AL
pros: The atmosphere and staff is incredible. I got to experience some really cool events and was able to write some really interesting pieces. Overall it was a great internship and I had fun getting to know everyone and the healthcare field.
cons: Sometimes I wasn't busy enough for my taste, even though I'd ask around for work. During slow times they just don't have a lot for you to do sometimes. Not necessarily their fault.

pros: I enjoyed my time at COA even though it was short. I learned a lot about the healthcare industry but you have to be able to deal with working with people who are more than willing to dump their "homework" on you. It's OK because the more you do, the more you learn and will help you in the long term.
cons: Lots of gossip goes around. Just be sure to stay out of it!

pros: This is a great hospital, providing excellent healthcare to children.
cons: The new nursing administration (at the top) began making changes in 2011 that greatly impacted the overall morale and satisfaction of the nursing staff; and also hindered their ability to provide the excellent nursing care that Children's Hospital has always been known for.

pros: Although the work is challenging, the environment is wonderful--pediatric medicine in a state of the art facility level 1 trauma center is extremely rewarding.
cons: The pay could be better. Because Birmingham is one of the bigger medical centers in the Southeast, there are many nursing schools that feed graduates into the system, making us underpaid on the whole for what we do.
